text: Is there a better solution to what I am trying to do? The reason I don't want a 4D arrays is that the length of the 2D arrays is in general different.

elements.text: Is there a better solution to what I am trying to do? The reason I don't want a 4D arrays is that the length of the 2D arrays is in general different.

text: Let's say I have a 2D matrix. Each entry in this matrix is an array, but they all have different sizes.

elements.text: Let's say I have a 2D matrix. Each entry in this matrix is an array, but they all have different sizes.

text: Creating a huge 3D array and only partially filling it in would be one option, but I kind of don't want to do that.

text: ok.  The important fact is be they vectors or matrices, they are either all vectors or all matrices (is that correct)?

text: Aright.  A couple of facts.  (that does not matter now -- I needed a general sense of your plan, that's all)

text:
The StaticArrays package is tremendous; it gets wide and deep use.  The way that it works, its implementation, limits the sizes that it will handle well.  A vector of 100 elements or a 12x12 matrix will perform very nicely implemented with StaticArrays.  On the other hand, A vector of 1_000 elements, or a 25x25 matrix are not appropriate for that package.

For large sparse matrices there is a very professional  datatype built-in with Julia.
`SparseArrays`.  `using SparseArrays`  gets you to it (this is one of the standard librarys, as are `Dates` and `LinearAlgebra`  and `Random`).   see the docs:
<https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1.6-dev/stdlib/SparseArrays/>

A vector of 100 elements or a 12x12 matrix will perform very nicely implemented with StaticArrays.  On the other hand, A vector of 1_000 elements, or a 25x25 matrix are not appropriate for that package.

For large sparse matrices there is a very professional  datatype built-in with Julia.
SparseArrays

text: Thanks, I will check that out.

elements.text: Thanks, I will check that out.

text: What  if my arrays didn't vary in size. Would the StaticArrays still not be appropriate for very large arrays?

elements.text: What  if my arrays didn't vary in size. Would the StaticArrays still not be appropriate for very large arrays?

text:
This may be the better choice for your outer structure.  The cells of your outer structure are going to be dense vectors, when they exist, so using one of the `AbstractVector` types makes sense.  --- If your arrays had no more than, say, well here it is from them:

```Note that in the current implementation, working with large StaticArrays puts a lot of stress on the compiler, and becomes slower than Base.Array as the size increases. A very rough rule of thumb is that you should consider using a normal Array for arrays larger than 100 elements. ```

elements.text: This may be the better choice for your outer structure.  The cells of your outer structure are going to be dense vectors, when they exist, so using one of the
AbstractVector
types makes sense.  --- If your arrays had no more than, say, well here it is from them:

Note that in the current implementation, working with large StaticArrays puts a lot of stress on the compiler, and becomes slower than Base.Array as the size increases. A very rough rule of thumb is that you should consider using a normal Array for arrays larger than 100 elements.

text: I see. Thank you!

elements.text: I see. Thank you!

text: You may as well work with the default vector type, it performs well and will handle millions of elements without blinking.  Let the helpdesk know if you have more questions.
